note: In Spain, cryptocurrencies are considered capital assets and are subject to taxation by the Agencia Tributaria.
Capital gains from selling, swapping, or spending cryptocurrencies are classified as savings income and are taxed at rates ranging from 19% to 28%, depending on the amount of gain.
Income from cryptocurrency mining is treated as a freelance business activity and is subject to Income Tax rates up to 47%, depending on total income.
Staking rewards are viewed as investment income and are taxed between 19% to 28%, depending on the amount of income.
Taxable events include selling crypto for fiat currency, trading one cryptocurrency for another, and using crypto to purchase goods or services.
Purchasing cryptocurrencies with fiat currency, holding cryptocurrencies, and transferring them between personal wallets are non-taxable events.
Spain uses the FIFO (First In, First Out) method for calculating the cost basis of cryptocurrencies.
Losses from cryptocurrency transactions can be offset against gains in the same financial year and can be carried forward for up to four years.
Residents with worldwide assets exceeding €700,000, including cryptocurrencies, may be subject to Wealth Tax, with rates varying by region.
Taxpayers are required to report their cryptocurrency gains and losses in their annual tax returns using Form 100 (Modelo 100), maintaining detailed records of all transactions.
The deadline for tax returns in Spain is June 30 each year, covering the previous financial year from January 1 to December 31.
Spanish residents must report cryptocurrency holdings over €50,000 held abroad using Model 721.
The Agencia Tributaria has the authority to track cryptocurrency transactions and holdings, especially under EU directives on data sharing and anti-money laundering.
Penalties for failing to report cryptocurrency income can include fines, interest on unpaid taxes, and in severe cases, imprisonment.
It's essential for investors to stay informed about the evolving tax regulations in Spain to ensure accurate reporting and compliance with the law.
